div.p:
there is a jolt at the points; the mind slides onto another
rail, lovely as the words are. To speak them the poet has
separated himself from the actors. He cannot yet make
speak those words. The play is still mainly (manly) the work
of the undifferentiated audience, demanding great names,
great deeds; simple outlines; and not the single subtlety
of one soul.

For the play itself was still anonymous. The lack of Marlowes
name is by itself (itslef) enough to show how largely the play was
a common product, written by one hand, but so moulded
in transition from actor to actor (acotr) that the author had no
sense of property in it. It was half the work of the audience.
Yet the audience is dumb. The silence of the audience is
one of the deep gulfs that lies between us and the Elizabethan (Eliza)
Elizabethan (bethan) play. The audience was a large one. Fifteen
hundred people, Dr Greg computes, was an average attendance (attanedance).
Their presence, in the penny part of the house, is obvious.
It draws up (pup) the hyperbole (hypberpole) as a sheet of paper
draws up (pup) fire. It makes the writer capable of great strides
and vast audacities beyond his private reach. Yet the audience (audiene)
sits silent.

To understand (underdtand) the silence we must compare (comapre) it
with our own attitude (attidtue) at the at the
in the early days. A new art comes upon us so (si) surprisingly (surprisningly)
that we are silent, recognising something that we cannot
measure. To the Elizabethans, the power of words after their
long silence (silnce) must have been overwhelming. There at the
or at the men and women who had never seen themselves
whose only reading was history or (historyor) sermon or some old chronicle (chornicle)
or perhaps could not read (r ad) but spent all their days in the
